snippet: Five years ago, rural America was giddy for ethanol. But nearly 10 percent of the nation’s ethanol plants have stopped production over the past year.
abstract: Rural America's days of promise and prosperity from ethanol are vanishing, as nearly 10 percent of nation's ethanol plants have stopped production over past year; production has become too expensive, due to drought-ravaged crops, and dip in gasoline consumption has worsened problem; demand for ethanol has shrunk to 8.7 million barrels daily from 9.7 million in 2007.

byline.original: By JOHN ELIGON and MATTHEW L. WALD

lead_paragraph: Five years ago, rural America was giddy for ethanol. But nearly 10 percent of the nation’s ethanol plants have stopped production over the past year.

headline.seo: Ethanol’s Days of Promise and Prosperity Are Fading
headline.main: Days of Promise Fade for Ethanol
headline.print_headline: Days of Promise Fade for Ethanol
